awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Intercellular regulation of protein oxidation during aging
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will identify new principles by which communication between tissues affects the oxidation of proteins as a function of age in a model organism, a roundworm. The simultaneous oxidation of proteins is increasingly recognized as an important means of coordinating protein function both within and between cells. Specifically, the oxidation of cysteine residues (an amino acid within proteins) plays an important role in regulating proteins involved in fat metabolism, gene expression, and cell shape. However, little is known about how cysteine oxidation is coordinated between cells because it has been difficult to measure oxidation non-destructively in live organisms. Recent innovations in imaging of cysteine oxidation in living animals enable the researcher to fill this critical gap in knowledge, which currently limits understanding of how multicellular organisms coordinate diverse cellular processes. It is expected that the proposed research will have a wide-reaching impact on aging, metabolism, inflammation, and other fields where physiological processes are influenced by protein oxidation. The project integrates research and education by providing research and learning opportunities on the science of aging for students in grades 6-12, undergraduate and graduate students, and the public. These opportunities include laboratory research experiences and educational leadership development for undergraduates, research modules that engage hundreds of new undergraduates in cutting-edge research experiences, and an open classroom that will outreach to hundreds of senior citizens and establish inter-generational relationships between them and students.

Cysteine oxidation disrupts enzyme catalysis and is an important regulatory mechanism for hundreds of proteins that control a wide variety of cellular processes. Little is known about the intercellular signaling pathways that can affect the oxidation of these proteins in a concerted manner. The objective of this project is to determine how intercellular signaling pathways regulate cytosolic protein oxidation in specific target tissues and with aging, using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans as a tractable model system. Protein oxidation will be measured with single-cell resolution in live animals, using a genetically-encoded, fluorescent sensor. The research questions addressed are: (1) How do sensory neurons regulate protein oxidation in distant target tissues? (2) How does local intercellular signaling regulate protein oxidation in specific target tissues? (3) How is the trajectory of protein oxidation with aging determined by intercellular signaling? This project will provide research opportunities in the science of aging for elementary to graduate level students, develop new courses and authentic research modules for undergraduate students, and improve public awareness and knowledge about aging science by offering courses designed to engage senior citizens.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this award, my lab delineated the roles of TGFβ, ephrin, and insulin/IGF1 intercellular signaling in the spatial and temporal regulation of protein oxidation across various target tissues in the nematode C. elegans. To support this work, we developed new image-analysis tools for ratio imaging in the nematode’s feeding muscles, intestine, and neurons, and created comprehensive documentation to facilitate community-wide adoption of these tools. We also discovered that C. elegans suppresses its hydrogen peroxide protective responses when specific sensory neurons detect signals indicating the possibility of freeloading on similar defenses from other species, marking the first evidence of this defense modulation in a multicellular organism. Additionally, we found that microbiome-dependent sensory perception of hydrogen peroxide by specific sensory neurons enables C. elegans to locate niches that provide both food and hydrogen peroxide protection. Last, we discovered that neuronal temperature perception induces specific gene-expression programs in the intestine, enabling C. elegans to cope with the enhanced reactivity of hydrogen peroxide at high temperatures. We developed a novel theoretical framework called "enhancer sensing," which explains the adaptive value of linking defense responses to sensory inputs that increase the need for those defenses and believe this framework will be particularly useful for researchers studying the evolution of sensory systems. The project resulted in 5 publications, 3 manuscripts in preparation, a web application, 2 open-source software packages available via GitHub, and 34 conference presentations (10 talks).

The project had substantial broader impacts. First, I developed a "Science of Aging" Project Lab course module, engaging 512 undergraduate students across 32 sections where they designed experiments and tested hypotheses related to aging. Second, to foster inter-generational connections and deepen students' understanding of the challenges faced by older adults, I introduced a service-learning component to my Cell and Molecular Biology of Aging course. In this course, 84 students contributed nearly a thousand hours of service to older adults in public housing and assisted-living facilities in Boston through partnerships with Little Brothers-Friends of the Elderly, a non-profit dedicated to alleviating isolation among the elderly. They also provided physical and emotional support during medical appointments for older adults in collaboration with FriendshipWorks, and relieved social isolation during the pandemic through remote service to older adults in Central Indiana, in partnership with the state’s Council on Aging. Third, I co-developed and co-taught an introductory genetics course at the Massachusetts Correctional Institution at Norfolk, through the Emerson Prison Initiative, which offers incarcerated individuals a pathway to a Bachelor's degree. The course aimed to diversify the curriculum by introducing science in response to students' interests. Fourth, I discussed the science of aging and potential career paths with hundreds of high-school students considering a career in engineering as part of the Building Bridges Outreach Program. Finally, this award supported the training of 6 PhD students, 1 Master's student, 41 undergraduates (including 3 Co-ops and 7 REUs), and 1 technician.
